document.masterDocTitle: The return of a forgotten harvestman: revalidation of Gonyleptes robustus Holmberg, 1876, as the second species of Acanthopachylus Roewer, 1913 (Arachnida, Opiliones, Gonyleptidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The return of a forgotten harvestman: revalidation of Gonyleptes robustus Holmberg, 1876, as the second species of Acanthopachylus Roewer, 1913 (Arachnida, Opiliones, Gonyleptidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Gonyleptes aculeatus Kirby 1819: 452
. Types : not specified in the original description, at least one male , D. Hancock leg. (supposed by Roewer 1923 to be in BMNH); not found, presumably lost.

Gonyleptes acanthurus Perty 1833: 202
[name made available by indication to Duméril’s (1823) illustration of the “Facheur acanthure”: Pl. 60, figs. 14–16; cf. ICZN Art. 12.2.7.]. Types :? (not found). Synonymy by Butler (1873) .

Pachylus aculeatus : Sørensen 1884: 641
(in part) [=
Gonyleptes robustus
, synonymy incorrect].

Acanthpachylus aculeatus : Roewer 1913: 51
(in part), NEC figs. 19, 20 [drawings display
A. robustus
comb. nov.
].

Acanthopachylus aculeatus : Roewer 1923: 412
(in part), NEC figs. 507, 508 [drawings are
A. robustus
comb. nov.
]; Mello- Leitão 1939 (in part): 623 [“Toute l’Amérique du Sud du coté atlantique”]; B. Soares & H.
Soares 1954: 233
(in part); Ringuelet 1953 (in part): 161 [=
Heteropachyloidellus serrulatus
, synonymy incorrect, referable to
A. robustus
comb. nov.
]; 1955 (in part): 283–288 [=
Heteropachyloidellus robustus
, correct under
A. aculeatus
; also the following incorrect synonymies: =
Pachyloidellus fuscus
, referable to
Pachyloidellus butleri
( cf. Acosta 1993 ); =
Heteropachyloidellus dimorphicus
=
H. paucigranulatus
=
H. marginatus
=
Pachyloidellus tricalcaratus
, all referable to
A. robustus
comb. nov.
]; 1959 (in part): 275 [=
Pachylus mesopotamogalis ,
synonymy referable to
A. robustus
comb. nov.
]; H. Soares & B.
Soares 1986: 87
, figs. 1–2 (in part) [=
Guascaia ypsilonota
, synonymy referable to
A. robustus
comb. nov.
];
Kury 2003: 154
(in part). NEC:
Acosta 2002: 81
(new material cited as
A. aculeatus
, corresponds to
A. robustus
comb. nov.
);
Acosta & Maury 1998: 580
.

Heteropachyloidellus robustus Roewer 1943: 18
, Pl. 1, fig. 6 [ Types : SMF, ♂ ♀ Montevideo , Uruguay , examined]. Synonymized by Ringuelet 1955 . [Potential junior homonym of
Acanthopachylus robustus ( Holmberg 1876 )
comb. nov.
; replacement name not applicable while under synonymy: ICZN Art. 11.6.].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Identification. Kirby (1819) described the spine-shaped apophysis on area V of male as “ spina aculeiformi validissima, incurva, acuta, basi sinistrorsum bidentata, dextrorsum unidentata ” [= a strong sting-like spine, curved, acute, base bidentate on the left, unidentate on the right]. As stated in the key above, one main difference between
A. aculeatus
and
A. robustus
comb. nov. is the shape, size and curvature of this apophysis: that of
A. aculeatus
being large and curved ( Fig. 2B , “ spina aculeiformi validissima, incurva, acuta ”), not inclined upwards as in
A. robustus
comb. nov. ( Fig. 2D ); moreover, the apophysis is frequently accompanied by additional apophyses on the sides in
A. aculeatus
( Fig. 2A , “ basi sinistrorsum bidentata, dextrorsum unidentata ”), only seldom in
A. robustus
comb. nov. ( Fig. 2C ). Also, Kirby’s (1819) reference to femur IV (“ Femora postica fusca, nodulosa, subtus prope basin spina validissima obtusa ” = rear femora dusky, knotty, ventral close to the base a powerful blunt spine) likely reflects one specific difference, considering that the basal large, blunt apophysis (“ spina validissima obtusa ”) of
A. aculeatus
( Fig. 2A ) is replaced by a truncated one in
A. robustus
comb. nov. ( Fig. 2C ). In this description there is no reference to any strong femoral curvature, a remarkable feature in
A. robustus
comb. nov. ( Fig. 2D ), so the later species does not seem to be involved.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Live males of
Acanthopachylus aculeatus
(A–B: El Caracol, Departamento Rocha, Uruguay; photos by Javier A. Canteros), and
Acanthopachylus robustus
comb. nov.
(C–D: Lago Lugano, Buenos Aires, Argentina; photos by Ricardo A. Palonsky—RAP). All photos used with permission of the authors.

FIGURE 2 . Diagnostic characters to distinguish male
Acanthopachylus aculeatus
(A–B) (MHNM, Departamento Lavalleja, Uruguay) and
Acanthopachylus robustus
comb. nov.
(C–D) (LEA 000.428, Sierra de la Ventana, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina). A, C: dorsal scutum, coxae, trochanter and femur IV, dorsal view; B, D: coxa (with rear end of body), trochanter, femur and patella IV, prolateral view. Scale bars: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
“Brasilia” (obviously meaning the country, not the present capital city); Montevideo , Uruguay , is presumed to be the probable locality for Kirby´s (1819) materials (see next section)
.

Distribution. Restricted to southeastern Uruguay (Departamentos Florida , Canelones , Montevideo , Lavalleja , Maldonado and Rocha ), reaching marginally the southernmost tip of Brazil along the Atlantic coast ( Fig. 3 ). A controversy may arise from Kirby’s (1819) statement: “Habitat in Brasilia”, what might suggest its occurrence somewhere in Brazil , not in Uruguay . With such old collections one should always be aware of potential mislabellings, so inaccuracies are to be expected; very often specimens were obtained during long-lasting ship expeditions, making port localities the most probable collecting points. At the early XVIIIth century, “ Brazil ” was, for many Europeans, much like a coarse geographical reference instead of a precise locality or country. However, it is worth noting that in 1816 the
United Kingdom of Portugal , Brazil and the Algarves
invaded and appended de facto the present Uruguayan territory (at that time still a part of the Provincias Unidas del Río de la Plata, four years later formalized as the Brazilian-Portuguese
Provincia Cisplatina
); invaders occupied the port-city Montevideo at the beginning of 1817 ( Halperin Donghi 2000 ). Thereby, even if the precise collecting date of
A. aculeatus
is unknown, the original reference can be considered consistent with the known range of the species.
